a-5.png.description: graph of g(x)= -5(2^x) : a curve coming in from the left along the x-axis, and curving downward quickly through a y-intercept of (0, -5)
a-5.png.source: Created by the Bootstrap Team in Desmos

a10.png.description: graph of g(x)= 10(2^x) : a curve coming in from the left along the x-axis and then curving up quickly through a y-intercept of (0,10)
a10.png.source: Created by the Bootstrap Team in Desmos

a2.png.description: graph of g(x)= 2(2^x) : a curve coming in from the left along the x-axis and then curving up quickly through a y-intercept of (0,2)
a2.png.source: Created by the Bootstrap Team in Desmos

b.5.png.description: graph of g(x)=0.5^x : a curve descending along the left side of the y-axis and flattening out along the x-axis,  passing through the labelled points (1, 0.5), (2, 0.25) and (3, 0.125)
b.5.png.source: Created by the Bootstrap Team in Desmos

b1.png.description: graph of g(x)=1^x : a horizontal line passing through the labelled points (1,1), (2,1) and (3,1)
b1.png.source: Created by the Bootstrap Team in Desmos

b2.png.description: graph of g(x)=2^x : a curve coming in from the left along the x-axis and then curving up quickly along the right side of the y-axis,  passing through the labelled points (1, 2), (2, 4) and (3, 8)
b2.png.source: Created by the Bootstrap Team in Desmos

difference-table-linear.png.description: A table with columns for x (1,2,3,4) and y (5,7,9,11), and arrows showing what is added between the y-values (2,2,2,2).

difference-table-quadratic.png.description: A table with columns for x (1,2,3,4) and y (5,8,13,20), arrows showing what is added between the y-values (3,5,7), and a second set of arrows showing what is added between the first arrows (2,2).

difference-table-exponential-1.png.description: A table with columns for x (1,2,3,4,5) and y (2,4,8,16,32), arrows showing what is added between the y-values (2,4,8,16), a second set of arrows showing what is added between the first set (2,4,8), and a third set of arrows showing what is added between the second set (2,4).

difference-table-exponential-2.png.description: A table with columns for x (1,2,3,4,5) and y (2,4,8,16,32), arrows showing the factor by which each y-value value is multiplied (2,2,2,2)

exp-decay.png.description: A scatter plot with points clustered vertically along the positive y-axis and curving to cluster along the positive x-axis

Simpsons_animation.gif.description: A scatter plot with multiple point clouds, each one showing a positive linear correlation. However, the clouds are staggered so that each one is lower on the y-axis than the last. Taken together, the entire set appears to have a negative correlation
